articles.content: Who could replace Japanâ€™s Ishiba as leader of the ruling party?Find out whatâ€™s new on ST website and app.Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba attends a press conference at the headquarters of the Liberal Democratic Party in Tokyo on July 21.PHOTO: REUTERSFollow topic:JapanPublishedÂ Jul 23, 2025, 12:48 PMUpdatedÂ Jul 23, 2025, 03:25 PMTOKYO - Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba plans to announce his resignation by the end of August, media said on July 23, following a bruising defeat in an Upper House election. articles.content: News analysisTrump piles up trade deals as Asia agrees to open up to American goodsÂ  Find out whatâ€™s new on ST website and app.US President Donald Trump with Japanese PM Shigeru Ishiba outside the West Wing of the White House in Washington, DC, on Feb 7.PHOTO: AFPBhagyashree GarekarFollow topic:Donald TrumpSummarySummaryTrump announced a "massive" US$550 billion deal with Japan, confirmed by negotiator Ryosei Akazawa, involving market access for US goods.Other deals with the Philippines, Indonesia, and Vietnam include tariff changes and commitments to purchase US products, establishing precedents for other Asian nations.Trump's tariff strategy aims to open markets for US goods and reduce imports, though experts debate its long-term economic impact and potential contradictions.AI generatedPublishedÂ Jul 23, 2025, 01:55 PMUpdatedÂ Jul 23, 2025, 09:32 PMAUSTIN â€“ Itâ€™s not easy to catch Washingtonâ€™s formidable trade lobbies and relentless, scoop-hungry journalists off-guard.
